script: It's me, daughter of Turning Water and Three Spotted!
My name is Cicada. I do not know Cho-hanna.
It was burned by soldiers when I was taken.
He's taking you to another home.
All the buffalo are dying… And we must choose… Make a stand or fall forever.
To move forward… you must first remember.
There is no time for stories.
It's good to be back with you all here in Wichita Falls.
My name is Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, and I'm here tonight to bring y'all the news from across this great world of ours.
Now, I know how life is in these parts, working a trade sunup to sundown.
No time for reading newspapers. Am I correct?
Let me do that work for you.
And maybe, just for tonight, we can escape our troubles and hear of the great changes that are happening out there.
Our own Houston Telegraph from 1st February, this news.
The meningitis epidemic continues to spread without prejudice across the Panhandle and North Texas region.
So far, it has claimed of the state of Texas up there in the capital… -There. -Much obliged.
It's all right. It's all right.
Go check it on that side.
Third Texas Infantry. Surrendered Galveston, 26th May, 1865.
Says here you're from San Antonio. What's your business up here?
I read the news from town to town.
I was headed down to the Red River and-- and I seen him.
I think he was transporting this little girl here for the federal authorities.
Looks like the Indians had her.
Here's her agency papers. Just found them.
-You're good. -What the hell do I do with this child?
Fetch her to Red River. Command post will know.
when they cleared the Kiowa out of Montague County.
You've been living with them since they kidnapped you, when they attacked your family in Hill Country six years prior.
Her mother, father and sister were… Well, they passed. But you have an aunt and an uncle.
So that's where you were being taken.
I used to live near there before the war.
Lot of German folk down there.
Kann-- Kannst du deine Familie… Remember your German family? Uh… Come tomorrow, we will find somebody who can take you home.
-What's your business? -Here to see your Indian agent.
He's up north of the Red.
Well, I found this child, see.
And the lieutenant who was patrolling the road told me to bring her to see you.
What do you expect me to do?
The agent won't be back for another three months.
Looks like you'll need to take her.
I work and travel from town to town.
Wait for the agent or take her yourself. It's up to you.
Good to lay eyes on you, Captain.
Wonder if I could have a word with you and Mrs. Boudlin.
Wait for the agent, it appears.
Got kind of a wild look about her, doesn't she?
All right, now, see here, child.
I have to work. You're gonna stay here with these kind folks.
She don't understand a damn thing, does she?
The Red River ferry is sunk near Cross Timbers.
…and parts down to Elm Creek are completely washed out.
Yanks sending soldiers too blue to muddy their boots, that's why.
Well, now The Clifton Record is reporting big changes that are coming to these parts that'll have a bearing on all of these travel issues.

On page one, The Pacific Railroad Committee voted today that Missouri, Fort Scott and Gulf lines are to be consolidated into a new line that will run from the Kansas border all the way to Galveston, Texas.
This will be the first railroad to cross the Indian reservation.
President Ulysses S. Grant… has ordered the Texas legislature to accept Amendments 13, 14 and 15 of the United States Constitution before any return to the Union can be considered.
Those amendments include the abolition of slavery… Say no to abolition. Never!
and the repayment of our war debts.
I say Texas first and damn them amendments.
I ain't digging no Texas soil, sweating and bleeding for some rich Yankee type.
What are y'all even doing here, huh?
You ain't dealing with the Injuns. Fixing our roads.
All they're doing is beating up on Southern folk!
Yeah, all right. I hear you. I hear you.
Northern blues are not helping us a lot.
And they're asking for a great deal in return.
But I'm thinking we got a part to play in all of this as well.
There's more than rain and Indians and Northern blues troubling our roads.
I've seen it myself, coming in from Wichita Falls.
-Thank you so much. -Thank you for your attention.
Excuse me. Pardon me. Pardon me.
I-- I was singing her a hymn, and I turned my back and she was gone!
She didn't take the horses. She can't be gone far.
Johanna! It's not safe! You'll fall!
I said she's wild. Didn't I say that?
Child's got a curse on her.
What the hell are you gonna do with her?
I found her. I'll take her.
Those roads have changed since you lived down that way.
Much obliged if you keep her. I'll be back first thing.
She ain't been used in a while, but still runs pretty good.
I, uh… I kept mine from Palmito.
Well, I'm sure you need it more than me.
I'll fetch it back to ya.
There we are. Come now. Come now.
Makes no matter to me what you wear.
We'll be on this road for about six days till we make Dallas.
Then across central Texas to the Hill Country.
We'll have to stop and give readings, of course.
We have to pay our way.
And keep an eye out for trouble.
Settlers killing Indians for their land, and the Indians killing settlers for taking it.
I guess you know something about that.
I'm Captain Kidd, by the by.
And it's a pleasure to make your acquaintance, make no mistake.
Please would be nice to hear.
Yeah, coffee packs a punch, doesn't it?
Bit more to your liking, huh?
printed in a line, one after the other?
Put them all together, and you have a story.
That's my wife… down in San Antonio.
I'm gonna get some more water.
Wanna make your fortune, that's the place.
that our nation, our great nation, must be made complete!
They paying you to take her home, or you doing it out of the goodness of your heart?
No, they're not paying me. I just know the road.
But I'll take a pair of rooms if you have them.
We don't use our hands and fingers. We-- Look. See this?
This-- This is how we eat.
And, uh, we-- we don't sing.
What y'all looking at? Ain't you never seen a child eat before?
She said you've been calling her the wrong name.
They cut it when they're in mourning.
This child is an orphan twice over.
Can you tell her that I am taking her to family, to an aunt and an uncle down near Castroville?
Kidd, she don't got any idea what that means.
Well, they're the only ones that will take her.
She's got no place else. Nobody wants her.
Mr. Gannett used to take them… before he went to California.
Maybe he just didn't wanna come back.
I do not have a clue as to the care of a child.
Never had the need nor the patience required.
She's still alive, ain't she? That's not nothing.
Sleeping through the night isn't what it once was.
Your stories can only keep you company for so long.
So, what you gonna do once you've taken her?
I may just keep heading south.
Work passage on a ship out of Galveston.
Go see those far-off places I… read about to people every night.
Isn't it time you went back?
Looking at you now… I'm thinking you don't have a choice.
Good evening. My name is Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, and it is an honor to be back in the bustling city of Dallas.
A busy town, and y'all are busy folk, so let's get right to it.
Now, when I got in yesterday, I collected the latest newspapers, looking for suitable readings, something to take us away from our troubles.
From The Times, on its page three… A word, Captain?
You take us away from our hard thoughts.
Lot of good it did us.
Poor men fighting a rich man's war.
Left us lying here in the gutter.
Way I see it, we fought, but ain't no piece of this ours.
It's late, Mr. Almay. And what is your point?
Point is, us old soldiers gotta live, right?
Got a little business proposition for you, seeing you traveling alone like you are.
How much you want for her?
This child is not for sale.
Word is she's that captive out of Wichita Falls.
Mr. Almay, you are well informed.
You can rest easy knowing at least she'll get paid.
I mean, look at that fair skin.
I bet you were a lucky man out there in the desert.
In the alternative, we could just take her.
Oh, thank the Lord. We're local traders, sir.
We became concerned about the welfare of this here child in the clutches of a strange man such as this.
I am responsible for returning this child to her family down south.
-That's her papers and my oath. -Stay still.
You take this girl and you get on your way.
I'm coming for you soon as I'm done with these blues.
You're good for a man of years!
But ain't you just so damn tired of all this?
Seems an awful shame for it to end like this when you can just join us.
This world, rich pickings for some, slim pickings for the rest of us.
You go. Take the horses and go.
No, no. No, this is worthless.
You have me in an uncomfortable circumstance!
How exactly are we gonna work this out?
I figure a share for each man and an extra for me!
Considering what you did to my associate over there!
That sounds pretty fair to me!
So what do you want me to do?
Just gotta turn over the girl, that's all!
Oh, Cap, what you trying to do, tickle us to death?
Well, we don't have a deal yet.
Aha! I think it's 'cause you're out of bullets, and all you got left now is bird shot.
Damn it, you have a deal.
I'm gonna lay my gun down on this here rock.
How about you do the same?
Then how about you do the same?
Well, now you done gone and spoiled it, Cap.
Looks like we're back on opposite sides.
Looks like I'm coming for you now.
Since you're so smart, prickly pear cactus.
Pear cactus. And there's juniper out there.
So, what else can you teach me in Kiowa?
Daw with a… is a spirit, a breath.
For us, it's more like a straight line.
We're all journeying across the prairie.
And looking for that place to be.
And when we find it, we go straight out and we plow it and we plant it all in a straight line.
Sehr gut, Onkel. You just spoke German.
You just leave that. You just leave it.
I guess we both have demons to face, going down this road.
Ain't nobody unaccounted for getting into Erath County.
I'm carrying nothing of any great value.
And your reason for traveling, Cap?
The news. I read the news to anyone with ten cents and the time to hear it.
I got the wagon cheap and the holes came with it.
Well, your newspapers sure got holes in them, mister.
There ain't nothing in here about Erath County.
Hell of a lot's been happening. Ain't that right, boys?
We done fixed them Mexicans. Injuns too. Pushed them clean out.
Mr. Farley, he killed a right smart of Indians.
We're building a whole new world down here in Erath County.
But ain't none of it writ here.
When he gets done here, bring him into town.
What business is Mr. Farley in?
-Mr. Farl-- -Business is never mind your business.
Is Mr. Farley family to you, John?
Nah, Mr. Farley, he ain't any kin of mine. No, no.
I ain't got no kin now Tommy's gone.
But I work for Mr. Farley all the same.
Mr. Farley gone shot him… for hollering and questioning.
Got thoughts of things in his head. He couldn't keep them in there.
Mr. Farley says to read this.
Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. My name… to read to y'all the news.
He's been kind enough to supply me with a copy of his own Erath Journal.
Sure looks like Mr. Farley is a very busy man in these parts.
He's an editor and a publisher, a businessman, a lawgiver.
And all of you fine folk working for him at that.
So let me see if I can't tempt you with something else.
The Harper's Illustrated, it has a story reporting from the lonely little town of Keel Run, Pennsylvania.
-I got a bad feeling about this. -Just give him a minute.
Now, Keel Run ain't known for much.
And I'm counting none of y'all have heard of it, since… Well, it is in the North. Why should you?
Keel Run is just one of a thousand little towns across our nation birthed by the work of many, but enjoyed by the few.
Now, Keel Run is no Durand.
It does not trade in buffalo, but in coal.
And just like you, every morning, its men rise early from their beds only to descend into the great, black coal mine.
On the morning of February 11th, 37 men of the Run attended their first shift at noon.
Keel Run's wheel of fortune had turned, for the mine, the coal mine itself, had caught fire.
The first dozen died in an instant.

But I'm not here to tell you the story of those unfortunate souls or of the mine owner who'd been so lax about their safety, sitting up there in his fancy home, counting the money produced by their labor. No, no, no.
I'm here to tell you about the 11 men who lived… …who survived that fire.
The 11 men who fought back against their deadly fate.
Thought I told you to read from the Erath, Captain.
Well, see, Mr. Farley, I was wondering if folks might prefer some storytelling Just for tonight, Mr. Farley.
I think you ought to read from the Erath all the same, Captain.
Sort of thing these people expect to hear.
How about we vote on it?
I can read from Mr. Farley's Erath Journal, or I can keep on with the story of the men of Keel Run.
Keel Run? All right. Very good.
That day, those 11 men were facing a mortal enemy… Go now. Shut this thing down. Go! Go!
-Show's over, folks! -Every pillar of progress of their own civilization.
I was just giving the people the choice, Mr. Farley.
You got no idea what we deal with down here.
Give them an inch, and every one'll slit your throat where you piss.
We have to stop fighting sometime.
Come here. Come on. Stand up!
I ain't never heard of news reading as a business before.
It's not a rich man's occupation, as you can see.
Well, so how did you bother in it, then?
I was a printer by trade, and I had a printworks in San Antonio.
When it was over, it was all gone.
Had to make a new life for myself right there.
I couldn't print the newspapers anymore, but I could read them.
And that's what I've been doing from town to town.
Left a wife in San Antonio.
Yeah, I heard all about Hill Country.
If they find you, they'd kill you.
Go make something of your own.
Say, Captain, those men holed up in that mine, they really beat the fire and get home?
Will you teach me that song you always sing?
The one that goes… Whoa, whoa, whoa.
We have to stay on the main road!
I wanna get you away from all this pain and killing.
To move forward… you must first remember.
This is-- This is where you belong now, Johanna.
I have business with the Leonberger family.
she always went her own way.
But she and her husband, Wolf, they wanted to be out there in the valley, where the land is cheaper.
You know, my sister, when we found her in the bedroom, they cut her throat.
The baby sister, they bashed the brain out.
Best if she forgets all that.
Who knows what they will have taught her?
But we must try to see her as a blessing.
And we need the extra hands.
You want money for bring her here?
No. No, I don't want your money.
You want some food for the journey?
You ungrateful girl. This man, he brought you on home.
Maybe she doesn't understand what's happening.
We'll have to inform Mr. Young about the rewriting in this contract, huh?
Gentlemen, this is… my dear old friend, Captain Jeffrey Kidd.
There's nothing you could have done.
It was being away for four years of war, Willie.
Four years with all the killing and all the blood.
Of wanting to go home every day.
Of wanting to see her and feel her.
To talk and laugh and dream… and think of having a family.
Instead, I got a letter delivered to my tent, saying she was gone and already buried.
God's curse on me had taken her.
It was sickness, Jeff, just sickness.
It was judgment for all I had seen… and all I had done.
I've known you 50 years… since we were boys.
We didn't ask for any of this.
But it fell to us to do the fighting.
It's just what we had to face and carry the rest of our days.
Yes… if that's what you want.
A man dead and buried has risen from the grave.
Three days ago, in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, a Mr. Alfred Blackstone of 47 years fell into a stupor.
His wife called the physician, but there being no pulse, it was determined that Mr. Blackstone was, most unfortunately, dead.
He was buried very swiftly on the grounds of the local church, where, as divine providence would have it, a wedding was due to take place the following day!
But nearing the church doors, the bride abruptly stopped.
From the cemetery beyond, she had heard this inexplicable sound… The desperate, unmistakable hammering of life.
In a state of frantic excitement, she ran to a nearby grave marked 'Alfred Blackstone.' And within moments, the entire wedding congregation was digging!

And from his widow Blackstone's embrace, Alfred turned to the groom and said, and I quote, 'Feller, when you get in that church and she says, Till death us do part, don't you believe a word of it!' My name is Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd.
That is all the news of the world we have for you.
We thank you, and good night.
